overview: The real estate landscape for 2026 is characterized by significant shifts in federal tax policy, a gradual decline in mortgage rates, and fundamental changes to industry association support structures.

A landmark tax bill, signed July 4, 2025, represents the most substantial change to the tax code since 2017, notably quadrupling the State and Local Tax (SALT) deduction cap to $40,000. This change is expected to incentivize itemization among homeowners, particularly in high-tax regions like California.
Concurrently, mortgage rates are trending downward, with jumbo loans reaching approximately 5.875% in early 2026, stimulating buyer demand.

The industry faces regulatory tightening regarding referral disclosures (via the new RAD form) and a transition in marketing group operations as regional associations like Bay East withdraw financial and administrative support.
Professionals are advised to prioritize meticulous record-keeping for mileage and home offices, as the IRS increases its focus on 1099-K reporting and cryptocurrency.
insights: ğŸ›ï¸ Tax Law Overhaul (July 4, 2025): SALT deduction cap quadrupled from $10,000 to $40,000, standard deductions increased (Joint: $31,515, Single: $15,750), Qualified Business Income (QBI) made permanent, and new $10,000 car interest deduction for US-assembled vehicles.

ğŸ’° Business Incentives Restored: Bonus depreciation reinstated for purchases after January 19 (100% first-year write-off for equipment/technology). Section 179 expensing allows immediate deduction of business assets. Real estate professionals must document 750+ hours annually to offset active income with rental losses.

ğŸ“Š IRS Reporting Changes: 1099-K threshold dropping to $600 for third-party platforms (Venmo, PayPal). 1099-MISC/NEC threshold increasing from $600 to $2,000. Cryptocurrency tracking significantly enhanced with stricter reporting requirements for all crypto-related investments.

ğŸ” Audit Red Flags & Best Practices: Maintain separate business/personal accounts to avoid co-mingling. Document mileage with contemporary logs ($0.70/mile for 2025). Obtain oil changes in December/January for odometer verification. Ensure expenses are 'ordinary and necessary' - avoid excessive luxury claims.

ğŸ“‹ New RAD Form Requirement: California Association of Realtors mandates Referral Addendum Disclosure form for complete transparency in referral compensation. Must disclose every detail of compensation received for referrals to eliminate 'secret' payments.

ğŸ¢ Bay East Association Withdrawal: As of January 30, 2026, Bay East ends financial/staff support for local marketing groups (Tri-City, Castro Valley, Pleasanton). Groups must become self-sustaining through sponsorships, merge, or disband. Some brokerages offering free venues to maintain networking opportunities.

ğŸ’¡ Strategic Tax Planning: Independent contractors face two paths - (1) Tax Minimization: maximize expenses to lower net income and tax burden, or (2) Income Justification: show higher net income for loan qualification while contributing up to $70,000 (or 25% of income) to self-employment retirement accounts. Ages 60-63 qualify for 'Super Catch-Up' provision with additional $11,000 retirement contributions.

ğŸ“‰ Interest Rate Environment: Jumbo loan rates decreased from 6% to 5.875% for zero-point loans, stimulating buyer demand. Properties in $1.1M-$1.2M range attracting 50+ buyers at open houses. Bond market (not Federal Reserve) remains primary driver of rate movements.

ğŸ¡ Down Payment Assistance Programs: Zero-Down options available (second mortgage for 3% down at ~6.75% rate, 600+ credit score required). CalHFA 'Dream for All' provides 20% down via equity-share (state receives 20% of appreciation), limited to first-generation homebuyers, lottery selection in April 2026. Alameda County program lotteries held annually in May and September.
